senses.de: To make something stronger, especially by adding more material or detail to it.
senses.ex: The bridge had to be reinforced to carry the heavy trucks.

Tips.title: Physical Strengthening
Tips.description: Used when physical objects like buildings or structures are made stronger or more secure.
Tips.example: The workers used steel beams to reinforce the old walls.

Tips.title: Adding Details
Tips.description: Applies when extra information or clarification makes an argument or idea more convincing.
Tips.example: The lawyer reinforced his argument with new evidence.

senses.de: To encourage or give support to an idea, a feeling, or a habit, so that it becomes stronger or more likely to happen.
senses.ex: Her resolve was reinforced by the support she received from her family.

Tips.title: Emotional Support
Tips.description: Refers to actions or words that make someone's feelings or beliefs stronger.
Tips.example: Their kind words reinforced my determination to succeed.

Tips.title: Habit Formation
Tips.description: Used when certain behaviors are promoted or made more habitual through repetition or encouragement.
Tips.example: Daily practice reinforced his language learning skills.

senses.de: To enhance the effectiveness of a military force by providing additional personnel or equipment.
senses.ex: The troops were reinforced with supplies and weapons.

Tips.title: Military Support
Tips.description: In military context, it means adding more forces or equipment to strengthen a group.
Tips.example: The squad was reinforced with additional soldiers.

Tips.title: Technical Context
Tips.description: The term is often used in technical or specialized situations like military operations.
Tips.example: Commanders planned to reinforce the front lines overnight.

Bolster.wordDefinition:
Both bolster and reinforce mean to strengthen or support something.

However, bolster often refers to providing extra support or encouragement to someone or something, like bolstering someone's confidence before a big test.

Bolster is more about emotional or moral support, while reinforce is more about physical or structural support.

Brace.wordDefinition:
Brace means to support or strengthen something that is weak or wobbly. For example, you might need to brace a bookshelf that's about to fall over by attaching it to the wall.

You use brace to prop up something that is weak, and you use reinforce to make something stronger.

Buttress.wordDefinition:
Buttress means to provide extra support or stability to something, usually a building or structure. It is applicable when an existing structure needs more support to prevent it from collapsing or falling apart.

Buttress is used to provide support, while reinforce is used to make something stronger.

Fortify.wordDefinition:
Fortify means to strengthen something by adding more protection or building up its defenses.

While both words mean to make something stronger, fortify suggests adding more features or construction, while reinforce suggests adding more support or assistance.

Prop up.wordDefinition:
The words prop up and reinforce both refer to the act of providing support or making something stronger.

However, prop up typically implies providing temporary support to prevent something from falling or failing, while reinforce refers to making something stronger or more enduring over the long term.

For example, if a table leg is wobbly, you might "prop it up" temporarily with a book or piece of wood until you can fix it properly.

If you want to reinforce a wooden beam in a house that may be prone to rotting, you might add extra supports or braces to make sure it stays strong over the years.

Prop up is more short-term and reactive, while reinforce is more proactive and focused on long-term stability.

Strengthen.wordDefinition:
Strengthen is a general term used when you want to make something stronger or more resilient.

It can be applied to a wide range of situations, from physical strength to emotional resilience. For example, you might strengthen your muscles through exercise, or strengthen your relationships by communicating more effectively.

Reinforce is more specific and typically refers to physical structures or materials, while strengthen is a more general term that can be applied to various aspects of life.

Support.wordDefinition:
Support means to provide assistance or help. It is applicable when someone or something needs help or backup.

For example, supporting a friend who is going through a tough time.

Reinforce is used when something needs to be made stronger while support is used when someone or something needs help or assistance.

Underpin.wordDefinition:
Underpin means to provide a foundation or support for something new or unstable.

It is used when you want to create a strong and stable foundation for something that is not yet established. For example, creating an apprenticeship program to underpin a company's future workforce.

quotes.Text: When you buy into the cultural idea of what's acceptable and unacceptable, you reinforce negative stereotypes and prejudices. That wouldn't work for me. I don't love to give advice to anyone, because we all have to make our own choices, but I'd want to live my life in truth.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Kerry Washington

quotes.Text: Reporters tend to find in others what they are suited to find, so there is a whole school of reporting where they are cynical about the world, and everything reinforces that. Whereas I tend to be optimistic and be amused by people and like them, even rather bad people.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Ira Glass

quotes.Text: Positive leadership - conveying the idea that there is always a way forward - is so important, because that is what you are here for - to figure out how to move the organization forward. Critical to doing that is reinforcing the idea that everyone is included.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Alan Mulally

quotes.Text: All too often, government's response to social breakdown has been a classic case of 'patching' - a case of handing money out, containing problems and limiting the damage but, in doing so, supporting - even reinforcing - dysfunctional behaviour.
quotes.Title: British Politician
quotes.Name: Iain Duncan Smith

quotes.Text: I liked the game, I enjoyed the game, and the game fed me enough, and gave me enough rewards to reinforce that this is something that I should spend time doing, and that I could possibly make a priority in my life, versus other sports.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Julius Erving

quotes.Text: Everything about my life was culturally rich, and all the people I met sort of reinforced the wackiness that was normally inside of me. No one said, 'You can't do that,' until I got to real record companies, that is.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Nile Rodgers

quotes.Text: I am happy to say that everyone that I have met in my life, I have gained something from them; be it negative or positive, it has enforced and reinforced my life in some aspect.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Walter Payton

quotes.Text: I often think you bring unhappiness on yourself, because if you don't like yourself very much, you allow yourself to be influenced by people who reinforce that.
quotes.Title: American Cartoonist
quotes.Name: Lynn Johnston

quotes.Text: A greater focus on design in all new homes would make the best use of land, create homes and public spaces, and reinforce the structures of urban life.
quotes.Title: British Architect
quotes.Name: Richard Rogers

quotes.Text: The differences between friends cannot but reinforce their friendship.
quotes.Title: Chinese Leader
quotes.Name: Mao Zedong
